metadata.case_name: Criminal Appeals Nos. 53 and 54 of 1956 (State and Mahesh Desai v. Respondents)

facts.text: Murder of Nand Kumar Chaubey, a peon of Bagdigi colliery, committed in the course of a serious riot on February 20, 1954, resulting from differences between two rival labour-unions in connection with a strike.

Prosecution launched on first information report by Ram Naresh Pandey against 28 persons, including Mahesh Desai under s. 302/109 IPC for abetting the murder by speeches and exhortations at meetings the day previous to the murder.

In FIR, Mahesh Desai accused of holding meetings on Friday morning and evening (about 6:30 p.m. and 7:30 p.m.), exhorting laborers to stop work, remain prepared, finish the dalals, saying 'It is necessary for us to finish the dalals for achieving victory. You remain prepared for this.' and 'Finish all. What will happen will be seen.' Information based on Jadubans Tiwary, who heard from Sheoji Singh and Ramdhar Singh.
Phagu Dusadh, Jalo Dusadh, Haricharan Dusadh and others chased Nand Kumar Chaubey, Phagu gave pharsa blow, Haricharan lathi blow, leading to his death.

Public Prosecutor applied for withdrawal u/s 494 CrPC against Mahesh Desai only on December 6, 1954, at commitment stage before Magistrate, before any evidence taken. Ground: evidence available meagre, single item of dubious nature, not likely to establish prima facie case, not just and expedient to proceed.
Subordinate Judge-Magistrate of Dhanbad granted consent, discharged Mahesh Desai u/s 494(a) CrPC.

Revision petition filed jointly by first informant Ram Naresh Pandey and widow of deceased against discharge order, upheld by Sessions Judge of Manbhum-Singhbhum on January 10, 1955 in Criminal Revision No. 43 of 1954.

Private parties applied to Patna High Court in Criminal Revision No. 102 of 1955; Chief Justice set aside discharge on May 31, 1955, holding no judicial exercise of discretion, directed Magistrate to record evidence and consider prima facie case.
State (Advocate-General of Bihar) appealed to Supreme Court in Appeal No. 53; Mahesh Desai in Appeal No. 54 by special leave.

legal_issues.text: Whether, where application for withdrawal u/s 494 CrPC made on ground of insufficiency or meagreness of reliable evidence, it is improper exercise of discretion for Court to grant consent before evidence taken, if reasonably satisfied that evidence not likely to result in conviction.
Whether s. 494 CrPC applies to commitment stage (preliminary inquiry) in Sessions triable cases.

petitioner_arguments.text: Public Prosecutor has executive discretion to withdraw u/s 494 subject to Court's consent; Court exercises judicial discretion to check if executive function improperly exercised or interferes with normal course of justice for illegitimate reasons; can rely on available material without recording evidence; consent proper before evidence if PP's view reasonable.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s. 494 CrPC; Bawa Faqir Singh v. King Emperor

petitioner_arguments.text: s. 494 wide enough to cover commitment stage in Sessions cases; no distinction between inquiry and trial; historical evolution confirms applicability at any stage before judgment/verdict.

respondent_arguments.text: Where withdrawal sought on ground of no/meagre evidence, Court must record evidence judicially before granting consent; procedure followed tantamount to pre-judging sufficiency; surrenders function to PP.

s. 494 not applicable at commitment stage in Sessions cases; applies only after case reaches trial stage, as per wording 'in cases tried by jury before verdict, in other cases before judgment'; 'tried' excludes inquiry.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s. 494 CrPC; s. 4(k) CrPC; English nolle prosequi analogy

court_reasoning.text: s. 494 enables PP to seek withdrawal; Court gives consent as judicial function to ensure no improper exercise by executive or abuse of justice; not to determine triable issue on judicial evidence; can consider available material (FIR, police statements) without recording evidence.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Initiative with PP; Court checks propriety, not prospects of conviction de novo.

court_reasoning.text: Evidence against Mahesh Desai meagre (based on hearsay in FIR via Jadubans Tiwary etc.); PP's view reasonable; no better material shown by complainants; Magistrate/Sessions Judge properly exercised discretion.
court_reasoning.key_observation: FIR allegations of exhortations not strong enough for conviction.

court_reasoning.text: s. 494 applies at any stage including commitment/inquiry in Sessions cases; wide language; no discrimination for jury cases; 'tried' not limited to post-inquiry; history (1872 s.61, 1882 s.494) confirms; results in discharge/acquittal per stage.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Phrase 'in other cases before judgment' covers all non-jury cases fully.

holdings.text: Court may grant consent u/s 494 before evidence on insufficiency ground if satisfied on available material that PP's view reasonable and no abuse.
s. 494 CrPC applicable at commitment stage in Sessions triable cases.

precedents_cited.case_name: Bawa Faqir Singh v. The King Emperor
precedents_cited.relevance: s.494 gives general executive discretion to PP subject to Court consent on many grounds.
Withdrawal may be for reasons not confined to judicial prospects.
Withdrawal may be for reasons not confined to judicial prospects.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898
statutes_cited.relevance: s.494 enables PP withdrawal with Court consent at any stage before judgment/verdict, resulting in discharge/acquittal; Court discretion judicial but not requiring full evidence; analogous to other Magistrate functions during investigation.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Prosecution against Mahesh Desai for abetment of murder.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court allowed both appeals, set aside Patna High Court order dated May 31, 1955, restored Magistrate's discharge order of Mahesh Desai; held consent u/s 494 proper before evidence on available material; applicable at commitment stage.
outcome.relief_granted: Discharge of Mahesh Desai restored; prosecution against him withdrawn.

key_quotes.text: "Section 494 of the Code of Criminal Procedure gives a general executive discretion to the Public Prosecutor to withdraw from the prosecution subject to the consent of the Court, which may be determined on many possible grounds."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines scope of PP discretion and Court role.

key_quotes.text: "The judicial function, therefore, implicit in the exercise of the judicial discretion for granting the consent would normally mean that the Court has to satisfy itself that the executive function of the Public Prosecutor has not been improperly exercised."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "This is not a case where there is no evidence on the contrary, this is a case where there is evidence which requires judicial consideration."
key_quotes.speaker: lower_court
key_quotes.significance: High Court view rejected by SC.
